title: Girls behind their boys
text:
Weather: Cairns 21 °C - 28 °C . Shower or two. Sport Cairns family cheers on Cowboys through the generations by: BIRTHRIGHT: Three generations of Cowboys fans, police officer Hayley Firth, her daughter Olivia, 7, and mother Jacky, will be glued to Jacky’s telly for the big match. PICTURE: ANNA ROGERS Source: News Limited 
CAIRNS schoolgirl Olivia Firth wasn’t even born when the Cowboys last made the NRL grand final. 
But as a third-generation supporter, the seven-year-old will be cheering louder than ever tonight when the club strives to finally secure its elusive maiden premiership. 
Olivia’s mum, Hayley, and grandmother, Jacky, know all too well what a Cowboys win would mean for the region. 
For years they have watched their heroes fall painfully short of glory. 
“They’ve come close on so many occasions, it’d be such a boost for the town,” Hayley said. “We’ll have to go to Townsville if they have a victory parade.” 
As members, Jacky, Hayley and Olivia have been to countless home games and now feel part of the “Cowboys family”. 
Hayley said mingling with the players at club functions was always special for fans. 
“We met Ben Hannant and Lachlan Coote, and even had a photo with JT,” she said. 
“They’re very community-minded people, whether it’s visiting hospitals or supporting the kids. The Cowboys have done a lot for rugby league in North Queensland.” 
While she dubbed Johnathan Thurston a “club legend”, Hayley said players like Matt Bowen and Brent Tate also deserved recognition for making the Cowboys successful. 
The diehard trio will be glued to the TV at Jacky’s.
